questions.question:
Question 1: Otoendoscopy of a patient revealed cholesteatoma limited to the protympanum. Which of the 
following sites is being referred to here?

options.a: The developmental predecessor of the middle ear
options.b: The anterior part of middle ear
options.c: The part of the middle ear foremost in conduction of sound
options.d: The part of middle ear around the eustachian tube

questions.explanation: The part of the middle ear around the eustachian tube is referred to as the protympanum. The middle ear is divided into 3 main parts: • Epitympanum/attic- above the level of pars tensa, medial to pars flaccida, and scutum. • Mesotympanum- opposite the pars tensa • Hypotympanum- below the level of TM

questions.question: Question 2: Which is the narrowest part of the middle ear?
questions.explanation:
Mesotympanum is the narrowest part of the middle ear. Transverse diameters of middle ear at various levels are: • Epitympanum- 6 mm • Mesotympanum- 2 mm • Hypotympanum- 4 mm. 38 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: What is the distance between promontory and tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation:
The distance between the promontory and tympanic membrane, i.e., the transverse diameter at 
the level of mesotympanum, is 2 mm.

questions.question:
Question 4: In a patient with necrotizing otitis media, CT scans reveal erosions of the structures present 
in the epitympanum. Which of the following is least likely to be involved?
questions.explanation:
Footplate of stapes is least likely to be involved in the given scenario because it is not a part of 
epitympanum. Epitympanum contains: • Head of the malleus • Incudomalleolar joint • Short process and body of the incus 39 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: While performing tympanoplasty, the ENT surgeon notices that the floor of the middle ear is 
deficient. Which of the following structures is susceptible to injury?
questions.explanation:
The internal jugular vein is susceptible to injury in this given clinical scenario. The floor of the middle ear is related to the internal jugular vein. Occasionally, the floor is 
deficient and the jugular bulb is then covered only by fibrous tissue and a mucous 
membrane making it susceptible to injury during middle ear surgery. The middle ear can be likened to a room with a roof, floor, and 4 walls (anterior, posterior, medial 
& lateral), as shown in the image:

questions.question: Question 6: Which part of middle ear is formed by tegmen tympani?
questions.explanation:
40 
Sold by @itachibot The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear. It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa. It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as tegmen mastoidea. The following images shows the tegmen tympani and relations of middle ear:

questions.question:
Question 7: CT scans of a patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma reveal that the tumor has undergone a 
local spread, destroying the anterior wall of the middle ear. Which of the following structures 
is least likely to be involved?
questions.explanation:
The prominence of the facial canal is least likely to be injured in this given clinical scenario 
because it is a part of the medial wall of the middle ear and not the anterior wall. The anterior wall of the middle ear is related to the following structures: • Eustachian tube 41 
Sold by @itachibot • The canal for tensor tympani • Internal carotid artery

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following structures is not a part of the lateral wall of the middle ear?
questions.explanation:
The subiculum is not a part of the lateral wall of the middle ear. It is present in the medial wall, 
below the sinus tympani. The lateral wall of the middle ear separates it from the external ear. It contains: • Pars tensa lying opposite to the mesotympanum • Pars flaccida and scutum lying opposite to the epitympanum. Scutum or lateral attic wall is a wedge-shaped bone that separates the epitympanum from the 
external auditory canal. It can be eroded in attic cholesteatomas. Image showing the boundaries of middle ear: 42 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following structures is not related to the pyramid?
questions.explanation:
The round window is not related to the pyramid because it is a medial wall structure whereas the 
pyramid is a projection present in the posterior wall. Image showing pyramidal eminence: The pyramid has the following features: • It contains stapedius muscle and the tendon leaves the pyramid to attach the neck of the stapes • It divides the posterior space into a medial sinus tympani and a lateral facial recess. • It serves as the landmark for the second genu of the facial nerve and houses the vertical segment 
of the facial nerve & the nerve to stapedius. 43 
Sold by @itachibot • The aditus (opening to the mastoid) lies just above it.

questions.question:
Question 10: You are approaching the middle ear via the mastoid through the facial recess. Regarding 
anatomical relations of facial recess, which of the following is true?

options.a: Bound medially by horizontal part of facial nerve

questions.explanation:
Facial recess or the posterior sinus is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is 
bounded medially by the vertical part of the facial nerve, laterally by the chorda tympani and 
above, by the fossa incudis. Facial recess is important surgically, as direct access can be made through this into the middle ear 
without disturbing the posterior canal wall. This is called intact canal wall technique. Image showing the facial recess: 44 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A child with cholesteatoma undergoes surgical removal via an intact canal wall procedure. 
Through which of the following structures is the middle ear approached?
questions.explanation:
In intact canal wall surgeries, the middle ear is approached through the suprapyramidal recess. Surgically, facial recess/posterior sinus/supra pyramidal recess is important, as direct access can 
be made through this into the middle ear without disturbing the posterior canal wall (intact canal 
wall technique). Image showing the facial recess:

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following structures forms the promontory? 32 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: The basal turn of the cochlea forms the promontory. The promontory is a bulge in the middle ear's medial wall, which is formed by the labyrinth. It gives 2 extensions: • Subiculum below to the round window. • Ponticulus to the posterior wall.

questions.question: Question 13: Which is the smallest bone in the body?
questions.explanation:
The smallest bone in the body is the stapes. It is also called a stirrup as it looks like the 
stirrup/footrest for jockeys while riding a horse. The malleus is called the hammer. The incus is called the anvil (large metal striking surface for shaping metals). 45 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: What is the type of joint between the middle ear ossicles?
questions.explanation: The type of joint between the middle ear ossicles is the synovial joint. The malleo-incudal joint is a saddle type. The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type.

questions.question:
Question 15: What is the structure marked in the given image? 33 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The marked structure is incus. This is an image taken during mastoidectomy. The incus articulates with the malleus and has a 
short process and a long process. The long process articulates with the head of the stapes. CT: chorda tympani; I: incus; JB: jugular bulb; LSC: lateral semicirular canal; M: malleus; PSC: 
posterior semicircular canal; S: stapes; SM: stapedius muscle; SSC: superior semicircular canal; 
VIIms: mastoid segment of VII cranial nerve; VIIts: tympanic segment of VII cranial nerve.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is attached to fossa incudis?
questions.explanation:
Fossa incudis gives attachment to the short process of incus. Fossa incudis is a depression on the posterior wall of the middle ear. It lies lateral to aditus ad 
antrum.

questions.question: Question 17: Which among the following structures covers the oval window?
questions.explanation:
The oval window is covered by the footplate of stapes. 46 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following structures vibrates when the stapes footplate is moved?
questions.explanation:
The movement of the stapes footplate causes vibration in the scala vestibuli. This is because the 
scala vestibuli, which opens at the oval window, is closed by the footplate of stapes. The scala tympani opens at the round window. Image depicting the transmission of sound:

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following covers the round window?
questions.explanation:
The round window or the fenestra cochlea is covered by the secondary tympanic membrane. 47 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is related to processus cochleariformis?
questions.explanation:
Processus cochleariformis is related to the tendon of tensor tympani Just anterior to the oval window, the medial wall presents a hook-like projection called the 
processus cochleariformis. The tendon of tensor tympani takes a turn here to get the attachment to the neck of the malleus. It is also the landmark for the 1st genu of the facial nerve and the geniculate ganglion.

questions.question:
Question 21: Impedance audiometry performed in a patient showed absent stapedial reflex. Which of the 
following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
The absence of stapedial reflex is suggestive of facial nerve injury among the given options. The 
facial nerve forms the efferent arm of the stapedial or acoustic reflex. Anatomy of stapedius muscle: Stapedius is a second arch muscle and it arises from the pyramid and attaches to the neck of the 
stapes. Its action is to lateralize the stapes & dampen loud sounds. It is supplied by a branch of the facial nerve.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following nerves supply the tensor tympani?

options.b: Branch from the medial pterygoid nerve

questions.explanation:
Tensor tympani is supplied by a branch from the medial pterygoid nerve which is a direct branch 
of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (and not the posterior division of the 
mandibular nerve). 48 
Sold by @itachibot Anatomical features of tensor tympani muscle: • The tensor tympani develops from the first arch. • Arises from the semicanal for tensor tympani in the anterior wall of the middle ear. • Hooks around the processus cochleariformis in the medial wall • Attaches the neck of the malleus in the lateral wall. • Action is to medialize the malleus & conduct sound. The posterior division of the mandibular nerve is mainly sensory and divides into three branches: • The auriculotemporal nerve. • The lingual nerve. • The inferior alveolar (dental) nerve. The motor component of the posterior division of the mandibular nerve supplies the mylohyoid 
and anterior belly of the digastric.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following cranial nerves provide sensory supply to middle ear cavity?
questions.explanation:
The sensory supply to the middle ear cavity is provided by the tympanic branch of the 
glossopharyngeal nerve. It forms the tympanic plexus with the caroticotympanic nerves from the 
internal carotid plexus of the sympathetic fibers.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following nerves does not contribute to the tympanic plexus?
questions.explanation:
The tympanic branch of the facial nerve does not contribute to the tympanic plexus. The tympanic plexus is formed by 3 nerves : 49 
Sold by @itachibot • The glossopharyngeal nerve forms the tympanic branch • The sympathetic fibers from internal carotid plexus forms the superior and inferior 
caroticotympanic nerve. The tympanic plexus innervates the tympanic membrane's medial surface, the tympanic cavity, 
mastoid air cells, and the bony eustachian tube. It also carries secretory fibres for the parotid 
gland, and in Frey's syndrome, the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve can be 
sectioned.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is true regarding the facial nerve course in the middle ear?

options.a: Horizontal in the medial wall, vertical in the posterior wall
options.b: Vertical in medial wall, horizontal in posterior wall
options.c: Horizontal in the medial wall, vertical in the anterior wall
options.d: Vertical in medial wall, horizontal in anterior wall

questions.explanation:
The facial nerve runs horizontally in the medial wall and vertically in the posterior wall of the 
middle ear. 50 
Sold by @itachibot The medial wall is related to the 3rd part, which runs from 1st genu (processus cochleariformis) to 
2nd genu (pyramid). It is called the tympanic or horizontal part. The posterior wall is related to the 4th part, which runs from the genu (pyramid) to the 
stylomastoid foramen where it exits the temporal bone. It is called the mastoid or the vertical 
part. Image showing course of facial nerve in ear:

questions.question:
Question 26: 36 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is true regarding the course of chorda tympani in the middle ear?

options.b: Enters middle ear lateral to tympanic membrane
options.c: Runs in between the malleus and incus
options.d: Enters middle ear via the canal of Huguier

questions.explanation:
In the middle ear, the chorda tympani runs in between the malleus and incus. Image showing the course of chorda tympani: 51 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 27: Which of the following is false about the lesser petrosal nerve?

options.b: Posterosuperior segment of bony external auditory canal

questions.explanation:
The fibers of the lesser petrosal nerve synapse in the otic ganglion and not pterygopalatine 
ganglion. The lesser petrosal nerve is the parasympathetic or secretomotor nerve for the parotid glands. It 
arises over the promontory of the middle ear from the tympanic plexus (glossopharyngeal nerve). Image showing lesser petrosal nerve synapsing with otic ganglion: 52 
Sold by @itachibot Anatomy of Mastoid
